query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 O poca nostra nobiltà di sangue, 2 se glorïar di te la gente fai 3 qua giù dove l’affetto nostro langue,
4 mirabil cosa non mi sarà mai: 5 ché là dove appetito non si torce, 6 dico nel cielo, io me ne gloriai.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Oh, our nobility of blood, how little, 2 if people glorify you down here 3 where our affections languish,
4 will never be a wondrous thing to me: 5 for there where desire is not twisted, 6 I mean in Heaven, I gloried in it.
**Cornish:**
1 O byghanta ni hon nobledh a wrek, 2 mar plysa an bobel a wra dhe’th fakya 3 ena-ji le may affection ny languish,
4 marvilis tra nyns yw dhe’m byth: 5 rag ena le may appetito ny tor, 6 yn kethva, vy a wra gloris.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
7 Ben se’ tu manto che tosto raccorce: 8 sì che, se non s’appon di dì in die, 9 lo tempo va dintorno con le force.
query.result:
**English:**
7 You are indeed a cloak that quickly shortens: 8 so that, if it is not lengthened day by day, 9 time goes around with its shears.
**Cornish:**
7 Mes ty a wra mantell a wra raccorce a-derow: 8 mar nyns yw appon diw in diw, 9 an amser a wra kerdhyn gans y forsow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
19 Per tanti rivi s’empie d’allegrezza 20 la mente mia, che di sé fa letizia 21 perché può sostener che non si spezza.
query.result:
**English:**
19 Through so many streams my mind is filled with joy, 20 that it makes joy of itself 21 because it can endure without breaking.
**Cornish:**
19 Dre so moy riverow yw an menes vy leun a lowen, 20 a wra letysi a-dro dhe’n hun, 21 rag yma yll sostenya heb torri.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Come s’avviva a lo spirar d’i venti 29 carbone in fiamma, così vid’ io quella 30 luce risplendere a’ miei blandimenti;
31 e come a li occhi miei si fé più bella, 32 così con voce più dolce e soave, 33 ma non con questa moderna favella,
34 dissemi: «Da quel dì che fu detto ‘Ave’ 35 al parto in che mia madre, ch’è or santa, 36 s’allevïò di me ond’ era grave,
37 al suo Leon cinquecento cinquanta 38 e trenta fiate venne questo foco 39 a rinfiammarsi sotto la sua pianta.
query.result:
**English:**
28 As a coal is revived by the breath of the winds 29 into flame, so I saw that 30 light shine forth at my entreaties;
31 and as it became more beautiful to my eyes, 32 so with a voice sweeter and gentler, 33 but not in this modern speech,
34 it said to me: “From that day when ‘Ave’ was said 35 to the birth in which my mother, who is now a saint, 36 was relieved of me with whom she was heavy,
37 five hundred and fifty 38 and thirty times this fire has come 39 to rekindle itself beneath its constellation.
**Cornish:**
28 Dell yw avyvys dhe’n spyr a’n gwyns 29 karbon yn flam, hemma a welas vy henna 30 golow a wra splendir dhe’m blandimenti;
31 ha dell yw a wra moy bella dhe’m lagadow, 32 hemma gans lagas moy dowes ha moy soave, 33 mes nyns gans an lavar ma a-lemmyn,
34 a leveris dhe’m: “Dhe henna dydh pan wra leverys ‘Ave’ 35 dhe’n genys ena le may mam, pyw yw ena sans, 36 a wra allevi a-dro vy ena le may vy oas pons,
37 dhe’y Leon y hanna kans pymtheg ha deg warnugens 38 ha tregens termyn henna golow ma a wra dos 39 rag rinfiammarsi a-dro y blannen.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 Li antichi miei e io nacqui nel loco 41 dove si truova pria l’ultimo sesto 42 da quei che corre il vostro annüal gioco.
query.result:
**English:**
40 My ancestors and I were born in the place 41 where the last sixth is first found 42 by those who run your annual race.
**Cornish:**
40 An tasow koth ha vy a wra genys yn an le 41 le may an kynsa seson diwethel yw kavos 42 gans henna renn an jowek blydhennel agas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 Basti d’i miei maggiori udirne questo: 44 chi ei si fosser e onde venner quivi, 45 più è tacer che ragionare onesto.
query.result:
**English:**
43 Let it suffice to hear this about my ancestors: 44 who they were and whence they came here, 45 it is more honorable to be silent than to speak.
**Cornish:**
43 Bas a’m tasow moy udyrn henna: 44 pyw oas henna ha le may yth dos ena, 45 moy yw tewa heb leverel ages.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 Tutti color ch’a quel tempo eran ivi 47 da poter arme tra Marte e ’l Batista, 48 eran il quinto di quei ch’or son vivi.
query.result:
**English:**
46 All those who were there at that time, 47 able to bear arms between March and June, 48 were a fifth of those who are alive now.
**Cornish:**
46 Oll an dus o a veu ena ena, 47 a alla armys ynter Marte ha'n Vatista, 48 veu pympes rann a'n dus a wra vyw ena.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Ma la cittadinanza, ch’è or mista 50 di Campi, di Certaldo e di Fegghine, 51 pura vediesi ne l’ultimo artista.
query.result:
**English:**
49 But the citizenry, which is now mixed 50 with people from Campi, Certaldo, and Figline, 51 you could see purely in the last craftsman.
**Cornish:**
49 Mes an dus a wra kemyskys, 50 a Gampi, Certaldo ha Fegghine, 51 a wra gwelys yn kler yn an artysan diwettha.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Oh quanto fora meglio esser vicine 53 quelle genti ch’io dico, e al Galluzzo 54 e a Trespiano aver vostro confine,
55 che averle dentro e sostener lo puzzo 56 del villan d’Aguglion, di quel da Signa, 57 che già per barattare ha l’occhio aguzzo!
58 Se la gente ch’al mondo più traligna 59 non fosse stata a Cesare noverca, 60 ma come madre a suo figlio benigna,
61 tal fatto è fiorentino e cambia e merca, 62 che si sarebbe vòlto a Simifonti, 63 là dove andava l’avolo a la cerca;
64 sariesi Montemurlo ancor de’ Conti; 65 sarieno i Cerchi nel piovier d’Acone, 66 e forse in Valdigrieve i Buondelmonti.
query.result:
**English:**
52 Oh, how much better it would be to be neighbors 53 with those people I mentioned, and to have your border 54 at Galluzzo and Trespiano,
55 than to have them inside and endure the stench 56 of the peasant from Aguglione, and the one from Signa, 57 who is always sharp-eyed for a bargain!
58 If the people who are the most degenerate in the world 59 had not been a stepmother to Caesar, 60 but rather a kind mother to her son,
61 then the one who is now a Florentine, and changes and trades, 62 would have turned to Semifonte, 63 where his grandfather went begging;
64 Montemurlo would still belong to the Conti; 65 the Cerchi would be in the parish of Acone, 66 and perhaps the Buondelmonti in Val di Greve.
**Cornish:**
52 Oh, pyth vyth gwella bos ogasow, 53 an dus dus owth owth a leveris, ha dhe Gemlydho 54 ha Trespyan dhe vos an keniver,
55 ages an dos dhe gul dhe vothan 56 an vilan a Aguglion, an onan a Signa, 57 neb a wra'n golon gwithys dhe vos an bargen!
58 Mar an dus a wra an moyha tralyna 59 na veu bos marow dhe Gesar, 60 mes kepar mam dhe'y mab, benigna,
61 henna gwres bos florentinek ha chanj ha merk, 62 neb a veu troys dhe Simifonti, 63 ena le mayth y'gan an kov dhe gerha;
64 Montemurlo a veu ethom dhe'n Konti; 65 an Serhi a veu yn plyw Akon, 66 ha mos yn Valdigrieve an Wondelmonti.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 Se tu riguardi Luni e Orbisaglia 74 come sono ite, e come se ne vanno 75 di retro ad esse Chiusi e Sinigaglia,
76 udir come le schiatte si disfanno 77 non ti parrà nova cosa né forte, 78 poscia che le cittadi termine hanno.
query.result:
**English:**
73 If you look at Luni and Urbisaglia, 74 how they have gone, and how Chiusi and Sinigaglia 75 are following them,
76 you will hear how lineages come to an end, 77 and it will not seem new or strange to you, 78 since cities have a limited lifespan.
**Cornish:**
73 Mar tus a wra gwel Luni ha Orbisaglia 74 kepar yns i, ha kepar yns a wra mos 75 wosa y Chiusi ha Sinigaglia,
76 ti a wra klev kepar an skathow a wra difanna 77 na wra'th parra nowydh poth na forth, 78 wosa bos an sitys a wra termyn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 Le vostre cose tutte hanno lor morte, 80 sì come voi; ma celasi in alcuna 81 che dura molto, e le vite son corte.
query.result:
**English:**
79 All your things have their death, 80 just like you; but it is hidden in some things 81 that last a long time, while lives are short.
**Cornish:**
79 An oll an traow a wra aga marow, 80 kepar dewi; mes yns kewsys yn nebes 81 neb a wra pader hir, ha'n bywow byskyn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 E come ’l volger del ciel de la luna 83 cuopre e discuopre i liti sanza posa, 84 così fa di Fiorenza la Fortuna:
85 per che non dee parer mirabil cosa 86 ciò ch’io dirò de li alti Fiorentini 87 onde è la fama nel tempo nascosa.
query.result:
**English:**
82 And just as the turning of the heavens and the moon 83 covers and uncovers the shores without pause, 84 so does Fortune do to Florence:
85 therefore it should not seem a wondrous thing 86 what I will say about the noble Florentines 87 whose fame is now hidden in time.
**Cornish:**
82 Ha kepar trohevel an nef a'n loor 83 a wra kovra ha diskouvra an letyow heb posa, 84 henna wra dhe Florans an Fortuna:
85 rag wosa na dhev bos parra marvilis poth 86 henna owth owth a leveris a'n uhel Florantins 87 neb a wra'n klow yn termyn kewsys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Sovra la porta ch’al presente è carca 95 di nova fellonia di tanto peso 96 che tosto fia iattura de la barca,
97 erano i Ravignani, ond’ è disceso 98 il conte Guido e qualunque del nome 99 de l’alto Bellincione ha poscia preso.
query.result:
**English:**
94 Above the gate that is now burdened 95 with new treachery of such weight 96 that it will soon be the boat's undoing,
97 were the Ravignani, from whom descended 98 Count Guido and all those who have since taken the name 99 of the noble Bellincione.
**Cornish:**
94 A-ugh an fordh neb ena wra karga 95 gans nowydh feleni a henna poos 96 neb a wra bys vyth yadhra a'n barka,
97 veu an Ravignani, neb a wra disens 98 an Kont Guido ha neb a wra a'n hanow 99 a'n uhel Bellincione a wra kemerys wosa.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Quel de la Pressa sapeva già come 101 regger si vuole, e avea Galigaio 102 dorata in casa sua già l’elsa e ’l pome.
query.result:
**English:**
100 He of the Pressa already knew how 101 one must rule, and Galigaio 102 already had the hilt and pommel gilded in his house.
**Cornish:**
100 Henna a'n Pressa a wydha ena kepar 101 reja bos a vynna, ha Galigaio 102 a veu ena'n chi doras yn aga chi.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Grand’ era già la colonna del Vaio, 104 Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifanti e Barucci 105 e Galli e quei ch’arrossan per lo staio.
query.result:
**English:**
103 The column of the Vaio was already grand, 104 Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifanti and Barucci 105 and Galli and those who redden for the bushel.
**Cornish:**
103 Meur oedh kolon an Vaio, 104 Sacchetti, Giuochi, Fifanti ha Barucci 105 ha Galli ha'y reudh rag an staio.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 Lo ceppo di che nacquero i Calfucci 107 era già grande, e già eran tratti 108 a le curule Sizii e Arrigucci.
query.result:
**English:**
106 The stock from which the Calfucci were born 107 was already great, and already had been drawn 108 to the curule chairs the Sizii and the Arrigucci.
**Cornish:**
106 An kepp a-dhia an Calfucci 107 oedh meur, ha deudhons gorra 108 dhe'n sedhow kurul an Sizii hag an Arrigucci.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Oh quali io vidi quei che son disfatti 110 per lor superbia! e le palle de l’oro 111 fiorian Fiorenza in tutt’ i suoi gran fatti.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Oh, how many I saw who are undone 110 through their pride! And the golden balls 111 made Florence flourish in all her great deeds.
**Cornish:**
109 Oh, pyth vy a welas an re beu disfattys 110 rag aga gorfenna! Ha'n bollow eur 111 a wra dha Vlores yn aga oberow meur.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Così facieno i padri di coloro 113 che, sempre che la vostra chiesa vaca, 114 si fanno grassi stando a consistoro.
query.result:
**English:**
112 Thus did the fathers of those 113 who, whenever your church is vacant, 114 grow fat by sitting in consistory.
**Cornish:**
112 Henaga wrug tasedow colon an re 113 pub travyth bys vyth eglosow vaca, 114 a wra dha voes rag gorra dhe'n consistoro.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 L’oltracotata schiatta che s’indraca 116 dietro a chi fugge, e a chi mostra ’l dente 117 o ver la borsa, com’ agnel si placa,
118 già venìa sù, ma di picciola gente; 119 sì che non piacque ad Ubertin Donato 120 che poï il suocero il fé lor parente.
query.result:
**English:**
115 The overweening family that grows arrogant 116 toward him who flees, and toward him who shows his teeth 117 or his purse, is placated like a lamb,
118 was already rising, but from humble folk; 119 so that it did not please Ubertin Donato 120 that later his father-in-law made them his relatives.
**Cornish:**
115 An lughtennow gorfenna a wra dha indraca 116 wosa dhe'n neb a dheu, ha dhe'n neb a wra dha dhiskwedhes 117 po'n pors, a wra dha dhaskelvelsa henvel,
118 oedh dheuth dres, mes a dus dus dus den; 119 hemma na wra dha Ubertin Donato 120 pan wosa'y thas-yn-le a wrug aga gerens.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 Già era ’l Caponsacco nel mercato 122 disceso giù da Fiesole, e già era 123 buon cittadino Giuda e Infangato.
query.result:
**English:**
121 Already was Caponsacco in the market 122 descended down from Fiesole, and already were 123 good citizens Giuda and Infangato.
**Cornish:**
121 Oedh Caponsacco bys ynwedh an marchas 122 a-dhia diskennys a-dhia Fiesole, ha oedh 123 da sitadens da Giuda ha Infangato.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Io dirò cosa incredibile e vera: 125 nel picciol cerchio s’entrava per porta 126 che si nomava da quei de la Pera.
query.result:
**English:**
124 I will tell an incredible and true thing: 125 into the small circle one entered through a gate 126 that was named after those of the Pear.
**Cornish:**
124 Yth wra vyth leverel travia ha gwir: 125 dhe'n kelgh byghan oedh mos dhe'n dhor 126 a veu henwysys a'n re a'n Pera.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Ciascun che de la bella insegna porta 128 del gran barone il cui nome e ’l cui pregio 129 la festa di Tommaso riconforta,
130 da esso ebbe milizia e privilegio; 131 avvegna che con popol si rauni 132 oggi colui che la fascia col fregio.
query.result:
**English:**
127 Each one who bears the fair ensign 128 of the great baron whose name and whose worth 129 the feast of Thomas comforts,
130 from him had knighthood and privilege; 131 although today he who binds the sash with the ornament 132 has gathered with the common people.
**Cornish:**
127 Pubonan a dhas an arwodh brav 128 a'n baron meur aga hanow ha aga prys 129 an goel a Dhommas a wra dha dhaskelvel,
130 a-dhia gensi milita ha privilej; 131 byttegens pan gensi pobel a wra dha junya 132 hedhyw an neb a wra dha wra dha fascia gensi'n freg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Già eran Gualterotti e Importuni; 134 e ancor saria Borgo più quïeto, 135 se di novi vicin fosser digiuni.
query.result:
**English:**
133 Already were the Gualterotti and the Importuni; 134 and Borgo would still be more tranquil, 135 if it were empty of new neighbors.
**Cornish:**
133 Oedh Gualterotti ha Importuni; 134 ha byth Borgo moy quïet, 135 mar beu digiuni a veu a-dhia nowydh vesin.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 La casa di che nacque il vostro fleto, 137 per lo giusto disdegno che v’ha morti 138 e puose fine al vostro viver lieto,
139 era onorata, essa e suoi consorti: 140 o Buondelmonte, quanto mal fuggisti 141 le nozze süe per li altrui conforti!
142 Molti sarebber lieti, che son tristi, 143 se Dio t’avesse conceduto ad Ema 144 la prima volta ch’a città venisti.
query.result:
**English:**
136 The house from which your weeping was born, 137 through the just disdain that has killed you 138 and put an end to your happy life,
139 was honored, it and its associates: 140 O Buondelmonte, how badly you shunned 141 his marriage at the urging of others!
142 Many would be joyful, who are sad, 143 if God had granted you to the Ema 144 the first time that you came to the city.
**Cornish:**
136 An chi a-dhia genys aga fletys, 137 rag an disdeyn just a wra dha verwel 138 ha a wra dha gorfen an aga bewnans le,
139 oedh onorys, henna ha aga consorti: 140 O Buondelmonte, pyth vyth drog vyth dhewis 141 aga nosow rag confortyow erel!
142 Lavur a veu le, a wra dha drysti, 143 mar beu Duw a veu dha gonnys dhe'vys dhe'n Ema 144 an kynsa prys a dheuth dhe'n cita.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
145 Ma conveniesi a quella pietra scema 146 che guarda ’l ponte, che Fiorenza fesse 147 vittima ne la sua pace postrema.
query.result:
**English:**
145 But it is fitting for that broken stone, 146 which guards the bridge that Florence made, 147 a victim in its final peace.
**Cornish:**
145 Mes ev a-dhodh dhe'n men tolmaen, 146 a wravyas an pons, Florens a wruk, 147 offryn yn y hedh dhiwedhes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
148 Con queste genti, e con altre con esse, 149 vid’ io Fiorenza in sì fatto riposo, 150 che non avea cagione onde piangesse.
query.result:
**English:**
148 With these people, and with others with them, 149 I saw Florence in such repose, 150 that it had no cause to weep.
**Cornish:**
148 Gans an dus, ha gans erel gansow, 149 yth welyas Florens yn-mes avel, 150 heb aghen a-gas dhe wetha.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
151 Con queste genti vid’io glorïoso 152 e giusto il popol suo, tanto che ’l giglio 153 non era ad asta mai posto a ritroso,
154 né per divisïon fatto vermiglio».
query.result:
**English:**
151 With these people I saw its people glorious 152 and just, so much so that the lily 153 was never placed upside down on a staff,
154 nor made crimson by division.
**Cornish:**
151 Gans an dus yth welyas y bobel gwych 152 ha gwir, kyns na veu an lili 153 settys bythkweth orth war an prenn,
154 na wul henna rudh rag rannvro.
